qas.question: What is undoubtedly a cause of the increase in obesity related diseases that are becoming prevalent?

answers.text: widespread application of some modern food processing technologies

qas.question: Aside from agricultural subsidizing, what else does the food processing industry influence in terms of political decisions?
What is perceived as the general priority of the food processing industry in this sort of economy?

answers.text: effective production of cheap foods with a long shelf-life

qas.question: The more expensive fresh foods have what nutritional value in relation to processed food?
Other than being cheaper, what is another main draw of processed foods?

context: As mentioned, lifestyle- and obesity-related diseases are becoming increasingly prevalent all around the world. There is little doubt that the increasingly <a0_0>widespread application of some modern food processing technologies<a0_0/> has contributed to this development. The food processing industry is a major part of modern economy, and as such it is influential in political decisions (e.g., <a1_0>nutritional recommendations<a1_0/>, agricultural subsidising). In any known profit-driven economy, health considerations are hardly a priority; <a2_0>effective production of cheap foods with a long shelf-life<a2_0/> is more the trend. In general, whole, fresh foods have a relatively short shelf-life and are less profitable to produce and sell than are more processed foods. Thus, the consumer is left with the choice between more expensive, but nutritionally <a3_0>superior<a3_0/>, whole, fresh foods, and cheap, usually nutritionally inferior, processed foods. Because processed foods are often cheaper, <a4_0>more convenient<a4_0/> (in both purchasing, storage, and preparation), and more available, the consumption of nutritionally inferior foods has been increasing throughout the world along with many nutrition-related health complications.
